field_edited_text.value:
Traffic Needs

O o o dd e dedgddaddd



heavy flow of through traffic across Baltimore, mainly along Route 1 in
the southwest and Route 40 through the center of the City and to the
east. It was easy to assume that through traffic constituted the bulk of
all traffic along these routes and that this would also be the case for any
expressway generally following this path.

This assumption was never correct. Every analysis has consistently
shown that through traffic was only a small fraction of total traffic. While
most past proposals for cross-town expressways have followed the Route 1-
Route 40 path, the reports accompanying these proposals have stated
that the great bulk of anticipated traffic would be local, and it has been
the volume of this local traffic which has been pointed to as the justifi-
cation for the proposals.

The most thorough analysis of through traffic on the City’s proposed
expressway system was prepared by the State Roads Commission in 1957.
This study showed that through traffic on the East-West Expressway
would range from 4% on the western leg to 6% on the eastern leg. No
estimate was prepared of the total number of through vehicles which
would travel the entire length of the East-West Expressway, but it is
possible to deduce from the study that this number would be substantially
less than 1,900 per day.

These results are in no way surprising. Studies and analyses in cities
all over the country have uniformly demonstrated that of the traffic com-
ing into a large urban area on any one major highway only a small
percentage is through traffic. The American Association of State Highway
Officials states that for cities of 500,000 to 1,000,000 this percentage is
usually about 8%. (The percentage tends to increase for smaller cities.
For cities in the 50,000 to 100,000 class it would be about 19%.)

The most certain fact about the East-West Expressway is that, if
built, it will be mainly utilized by traffic having origin and/or destination

16

in the Baltimore metropolitan area.

Effect of Transit Improvements i
Can improvement of our present public transportation system, or

development of some new form of rapid transit, minimize or eliminate the

need for additional freeways? Everyone would like to think so, but the

facts do not appear to be favorable.

Mass transportation is obviously a more efficient means of moving
people than private automobiles. A loaded bus occupies much less street
space than the number of cars which would transport the same number
of people. Rapid transit operating on rail lines takes no street space at
all. Furthermore, mass transportation eliminates the need for parking
spaces at destination points.

The fact remains that mass transit is not realizing these potentialities™

in Baltimore or in most other large cities. Since World War II there has
been a consistent pattern of declining patronage, deteriorating service,



Y
Y

i
A

!

and higher fares. The growing gap between possibility and performance |

plus increasing dependence upon the private automobile with all the
ensuing problems of congestion, need for expensive new traffic facilities,
etc., have focused attention upon the mass transportation problem.
Within the past few years a number of studies have been made of mass
transportation in the Baltimore area, notably the 1955 report of the
Commission on Mass Transportation (the Committee was appointed by
the Mayor and was headed by Dr. Abel Wolman), a report in three parts
issued by Mr. Henry A. Barnes, Commissioner of Transit and Traffic, in
1958, and an unpublished study prepared under the auspices of the
Regional Planning Council. All three of these reports emphasize the need
for improving mass transit and all are basically sympathetic to an en-
hanced position for mass transit in our overall transportation picture.
